title: My Digital Humanities Portfolio
text:
DH Program Logo



A portfolio submitted in fulfillment of the requirements of the UVA Graduate Certificate Program in Digital Humanities

title: About Me
text:
Loren Easterday Lee
I am the current Chair of the Graduate Student Committee of the Medieval Academy of America, responsible for all MAA GSC-sponsored programming. I likewise serve the UVA Medieval Studies Program, organizing events for all members of the UVA community of medievalists. For the 2024-2025 academic year, I am also the Digital Humanities Fellow of the Scholars’ Lab.
In addition to my studies at UVA, I have completed extensive coursework with Rare Book School, earning a certification in the History of Manuscripts. I was a pensionnaire étranger at the ENS in Paris for the 2023-2024 academic year at which time I was able to conduct manuscript research for my dissertation with the support of several major fellowships.
My research interests include representations of identity, women, and the body in pre-modern literature, particularly in hagiography. My dissertation focuses on medieval manuscript studies, digital humanities methods, editing, and translation studies. In addition to Modern French, I also read Old French, German, and Latin.
Before joining UVA, I earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in English Literature and French and Francophone Studies and a Master of Science degree in Theory and Practice in Teacher Education from the University of Tennessee, Knoxville. I then taught English and French at the secondary level for several years first outside of Montpellier, France and then in the Richmond, Virginia area.

title: Intro to DH
text:
DH 8991
I enrolled in DH 8991 with Alison Booth in Spring 2022. Below, you’ll find the course syllabus (adapted for Spring 2023) as well as samples of my work from the course.

title: Intro to DH
text:
Syllabus





Course Description
“This course is a graduate-level introduction to the history, theory, and methods of the digital humanities. We will cover a range of historical, disciplinary, technical, and contemporary issues in the field, primarily in the context of literature, textual studies, and history, but also spatial matters, database and network analysis, machine learning and its critiques. Our plan is to introduce diverse cultural and epistemological issues and methods. Examples include how maps and other spatial and temporal perspectives are enabled by the digital; the conditions of print and archival materials in the age of digital reproduction; emergent/cy concerns about textual analysis, AI, privacy, security, surveillance. This course is also designed to introduce students to areas of DH activity at this university. Students should come away from the course with a solid understanding of the origin of digital humanities, the kinds of work done under that label, the opportunities to participate in DH research at UVA, the research insights offered by digital methods, and the applicability of those methods to the student’s own research interests. The course is required for all students enrolled in the Graduate Certificate in Digital Humanities. Thanks to John Unsworth (whose syllabus lays groundwork for this one), and to Brandon Walsh and Brad Pasanek, with whom I taught previous versions of DH courses.”


Work Samples
Essay 1: Intellectual Autobiography (1st draft)
Research Intervention: useR! 2022 Conference Abstract
Essay 2: Embracing the Variorum (blog)
Curricular Intervention: Digital Editing & Medieval Manuscripts
Essay 3: Intellectual Autobiography (final)

title: Elective A
text:
SARC 5400: Data Visualization
I enrolled in SARC 5400 with Eric Field in Spring 2023. Below, you will find the course syllabus (updated for the most recent iteration of the course) as well as samples of my work from the course.

title: Elective A
text:
Syllabus





Course Description
“This is a course about information and data visualization. We live in a world rich with information. This course teaches visual and spatial thinking coupled with data analysis tools and custom web-enabled programming to construct and envision information. To find and even invent approaches toward seeing into complex problems, we will study, and make, useful, compelling and beautiful tools to see.”


Work Samples
Assignment 1: the Good, the Bad, and the Ugly
Assignment 2: Me, graphically





Assignment 3: Visual Data Analysis
Final Project, part 1: Ugly Sketch & Prototype
Final Project, part 2: Narrative & Reflection
Digital Project:“What can we do to better visualize manuscript size?”

title: Elective B
text:
FREN 8510: Race/Gender/Class in Premodern France
I enrolled in FREN 8510 with Deborah McGrady in Fall 2021. Below, you will find the course syllabus as well as the final outcome of my DH work for this course: a prototype edition and translation of Le Roman de Silence (verses 2439-2688).

title: Elective B
text:
Syllabus





Course Description
“This course will challenge the contemporary perception that medieval Europe was an all-white privileged masculine space by turning to creative works of the late medieval francophone world in which racialized, gendered and classed bodies take shape. Turning attention to medieval French works, ranging from romances, theatre, miracle texts to conquest literature, travel writing, and crusading propaganda from the 13-15th centuries, this class will pursue new avenues in Medieval Studies that engage with contemporary critical identity studies. We will investigate the role of power and privilege in the formation of premodern identity, the politics of othering, and the question of subaltern agency in late medieval society. Our investigation will lead us to take a new intersectional view of “othering” in medieval culture that will push beyond the categories of Muslims, Jews, peasants, women, etc. to consider the combined impact of religion, race, class, sex/gender, and disability.”


Final Project
Final Paper: “Translation Trouble in Le Roman de Silence: A Test Case in Digital Editing for Polysemy”
Digital Project: Digital Edition of Le Roman de Silence (verses 2439-2688)

title: Final Project
text:
Scholars’ Lab Digital Humanities Fellowship
In support of my dissertation research, the Scholars’ Lab selected me as their 2024-2025 Digital Humanities Fellow.

My Dissertation
Like this digital portfolio, I am building my dissertation, The Life of Saint Mary the Egyptian: A Digital Critical Edition of the Old French Version T with English Translations, as a Quarto Book.
I will defend in the Summer of 2025, and a preview of my dissertation may be found here: https://leeloren.github.io/dissertation/.
